>>9496654
Being poor third-worlders, at school we emulated the everloving shit out of those five games and G/S/C through VBA, usually sharing tips or teams. I played a common save in the library PC during recess with other three guys from my classroom, all doing a bit per day or picking one pokemon for the current team.
To be honest, I went through the 3rd gen games because I liked the new pokemons, it was my entry to 1st gen and I wanted to play more of the franchise, but it always felt like a downgrade to the GBC games; no visible day/night cycle, the gimmicky base building and contests and the music were things I didn't like over the simpler, more dynamic experience from the previous generation. I guess things would have been different if I had played them on the hardware and had traded and battled with other people as it was intended.
If I had to choose, though, it would be Emerald. The Battle Frontier was a great time sinker once you found that one place you liked and went through again and again, in my case being the Factory and renting pokemons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9498454
If they really wanted to, they'd find a way to make them compatible. even if it just amounted to cloning a copy of the original Pokemon. They had to figure out how to assign genders and shiny status for Gen 1 Pokemon into Gen 2, after all.
Instead they required no less than 4 games to catch all Pokemon that generation.

That said I do find it interesting since I'm willing to five GF the benefit of the doubt that it wasn't just greed like most people, but wanting to do a social experiment where they wanted to see how Pokemon would spread. I think it became more fully realized once online trading became standard, when D/P came out with online trading it was really cool to propagate Pokemon that weren't easy to acquire with the standard D/P games online. stuff like Johto starters or swarming /honey/mansion Pokemon that were rare encounters in game but easy to find in RSE/FR/LG.

>>9498630
I'm talking about something a lot greater than little callbacks or references. I'm talking about having a real plot and a main narrative that gets fleshed out, not reinvented, when Pokemon was brand new and not just another series that everybody knew the "rules" of how the franchise works, a lot of us viewed it differently. We expected our adventure in Gen1 and everything it presented from intriguing Pokemon bios, the cryptic story of Mew/Mewtwo etc, and even things from the anime to be laying the groundwork for some bigger narrative, but it wasn't...and that's where the disappointment lies. I remember being a kid and playing Saphire version and enjoying the gameplay well enough but just thinking "oh, so that's it....we're in a new region and there's a new narrative with new creatures, that really doesn't elaborate on or build off the last and creates its own new semi self contained story/mythology" and it was then I knew that's how Pokemon was going to work as a franchise, and it worked for them, keeping things fairly new each time is part of why it's so successful and easily adopted by each new era of kids, but it still disappointed a lot of us. If you came into Pokemon post Gen 1 when the rules of how Pokemon works as a franchise were established, it's probably hard to imagine a time when nobody knew that and assumed every little tiny detail in Gen 1 was a big deal that had something to do with a greater story

In retrospect, obviously not much thought went into the plot, but it didn't feel that way to us as little kids who took it very seriously

I think the original games had better music and a handful of better lines of dialogue, but FRLG was pretty great otherwise. I like held items, natures and all the other gen 3 junk and honestly like being able to play Red or Green with that stuff thrown in. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9499552
The only ones I find a chore are a small portion of Tall, Tall Mountain, and mostly the tiny side of Tiny, Huge Island.

TTM is too linear with ascending the mountain, and the camera angle is a little annoying for stuff like the red coins.

THM is just a nuisance to navigate as it can be too easy to slip up and fall off the island, because it's just too tiny.
Part of the problem is that the game's controls were fine tuned to the original N64 analogue stick which has a huge pivot. Modern controls have a much smaller pivot so finer movements on N64 games are unreliable. Think stuff like Bow and Arrow aiming in Ocarina of Time / Majora's Mask, it's an issue that persists in official releases like Wii Virtual Console.

posts.com:
My personal rank of Mario 64 stages would be:
1. Big Boo's Haunt
2. Bob-omb Battlefield
3. Jolly Roger Bay
4. Shifting Sand Land
5. Lethal Lava Land
6. Whomp's Fortress
7. Cool, Cool Mountain
8. Snowman's Land
9. Tall, Tall Mountain
10. Hazy Maze Cave
11. Dire, Dire Docks
12. Wet-Dry World
13. Tick Tock Clock
14. Rainbow Ride
15. Tiny, Huge Island
So the early stages dominate, there is a handful of okay-ish later stages, but I really just dread Tick Tock Clock, Rainbow Ride and Tiny, Huge Island. Their design is just not really fun to me.

>>9504971
Weaponlord was a super ambitious game that came out late in the 16 bit cycle. It has an interesting control scheme, parry system and weapon damage. It's very interesting, but runs like garbage because neither the Genesis or snes can handle what it's trying to do and because it flopped it was never ported or made better.

However, Namco was apparently very, very influenced by it when making Soul Edge. And indeed, if you want to imagine what playing Weaponlord is like, picture a 2D Soul Edge where everyone is a caveman stuck in molasses. So it has some legacy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I made a thread the other day about Metroid 1 and some people were saying Metroid 2 was a big improvement. I'm playing it now and I have to say that I completely disagree.
The controls are super sluggish, especially whenever you're in the air. In the first game you slowed down when jumping, but it still felt pretty satisfying; in Metroid 2 it's way too slow. Specifically, there's a big problem with how long you can hold the A button to jump. In Metroid 1, whenever you release the button, you immediately stop rising and begin falling. In Metroid 2, however, after a certain point, it becomes impossible to cancel out your jump, so even if you let go of the button, Samus will continue to rise, and this feels really shitty. If you've played the game you'll know what I mean.
The screen is way too zoomed in and it's retarded that there's no automap. In Metroid 1 they advised you to make your own map, and that's what I did, but such a recommendation is not repeated in Metroid 2's manual, and making your own map would fucking suck because of how zoomed in the screen is. So I've spent ages going over the same little bit of area with the shitty sluggish controls and ear rape music (trying to be suspenseful and atmospheric on the Gameboy was an ambitious concept but it falls flat on its face, it's just a bunch of irritating beeping) and can't find the gay fucking Metroid. I've got 18 left so I'm not even halfway through this bitch.
So the first game was definitely better. I don't know why they put a "mainline" sequel to the original on the Gameboy of all things.

>>9504004
Metroid 2 is split into very easily navigatable chunks of cave that you tackle one by one without ever having a reason to backtrack to anything earlier. This is specifically so you can easily keep the layout in your head and thus be able to play on the go without taking notes or drawing maps, which is why the manual doesn't recommend it.
If you can't find more Metroids despite not having activated a quake after your most recent kill, you always know it's somewhere within a few screens of you, so all you need to do is comb those screens over again to find whatever door you missed.

It was kinda cool back was a kid, but as a teen I started to absolutely hate MK, especially after I got into SF and later KoF. It just felt like Western kusoge that was nowhere near in depth, while embodying everything shitty about the 90s gaming—digitized sprites, edginess, ugliness, and so on. The controls were also stunningly retarded, with arbitrary motion sequences feeling archaic after SF controls that just made sense.
As time went, I got some sort of appreciation for MK3/U. But still, when you compare it to any SF game, it's pretty damn unbalanced (ask the game's community), with VERY samey movesets, and overall not a perfect a game by any means.

MOST games you'd want to play run perfectly, especially if you install a config file. PS3's are cheaper than a PS2+HDD Module at the moment, so check a compatibility list for the PS2 Classics emulator and see what you wanna play before you write off the PS3.
>>9503783
On a typical CRT the PS3 will output the remastered games at 480i which will usually be a higher resolution than the PS2 (games typically ran at 448i).

I've got NTSC San Andreas running on both a PS2 and PS3, but I think my PS3 might be outputting PAL60 or something since something is different enough about the signal that the TV automatically scaled my settings to adjust (even my service menu seems to be running at a different resolution).

Nevertheless, many PS2 games like SA were letterboxed and squished at 448i or lower, so I've stretched the picture on my TV settings (minimap would otherwise be an oval). Since the minimap is a circle on both, we can say that the PS3 doesn't stretch the picture to 480i and will output interlaced games at their original resolution.

Some PS2 games however run at 240p, which the PS3 will upscale to 480i since it cannot do 240p. Examples of 240p titles include Ico and Shadow of the Colossus. If you like how those games look on PS2, play the PS2 versions on a PS2 instead of the remasters. For the same reason, PS1 games (the majority of which are 240p) will be upscaled too.

>>9499306
Something I didn't see others mention that is a huge part of beat em ups is the fact that they are meant to be played by more than one person, with many even going as far as having 4 (and even sometimes even 6) sticks so many people could play at the same time.
The amount of fun playing with 3 more people in a cabinet is hard to explain. With all the monsters, the fighting for the powerups and health, saving a buddy by dropping with a new live/bomb drop, and all the hectic stuff going around.
Playing solo is simply not the same experience. I recommend trying to play them coop with a friend online, physically together would be even better.

As for a specific game, one of my favourites is Alien vs Predator.
It has the perfect amount of complexity in character moves and enemy patterns / powerups that you can always come out of a game session feeling like you got better and the next time you could squeeze more moves/better play from your character.
It's an important part of the experience too because beat em ups that are too simple get boring really fast if the only thing you do is press punch over and over with the occasional powerup and enemy that takes a ton of hits.

Turtles in Time and (not retro) Dragon's Crown are amazing too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>don't enjoy beat-em-ups
Everyone's recommending the D&D arcade games because they have an inventory system to add a layer to the gameplay. Also check out River City Ransom, which adds in an RPG-ish system of money, items, and upgrades. Aliens VS Predator leans heavily into weaponry over mashing the attack button. Die Hard Arcade is similar but also has special combo attacks worth learning. Battle Circuit is a bit like RCR, but without the ability to grind. Armored Warriors lets you use defeated enemy's weapons.
Don't play generic jump-and-attack-to-win games like Simpsons, X-Men, or Oriental Legends/Knights of Valour. They are flashy but just button mashers.

So what does this engine do exactly?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9504558

WHAT IS THE FORCE ENGINE?
==============================================
The Force Engine is a project with the goal to reverse engineer and rebuild the Jedi Engine for modern systems and the games that used that engine - Dark Forces and Outlaws. The project will include modern, built-in tools, such as a level editor and will make it easy to play Dark Forces and Outlaws on modern systems as well as the many community mods designed to work with the original games.

Playing Dark Forces or Outlaws using the Force Engine will add ease of use and modern features such as higher resolutions and modern control schemes such as mouse-look. Using the built-in tools will allow for easier modding with more modern UI, greater flexibility and the ability to use enhancements made to the Jedi Engine for Outlaws in custom Dark Forces levels - such as slopes, stacked sectors, per-sector color maps and more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I have a very weird contribution to this thread. Earlier this year I watched the Austin Powers movies for the first time and fell in love with them. I then went and looked to see if my hobby ever had crossed paths with these films I love and sure enough they had! 3 times in fact! I then promptly scooped em all up so I'm one of the few autistic retards who can say have a complete Austin Powers video game collection. One of which is Austin Powers Pinball for the Playstation. It's a pretty strange release, featuring only 2 tables based around International Man of Mystery and Spy Who Shagged Me despite releasing a little bit after Goldmember hit theaters. The physics are fine I suppose, standard pinball fare, but the game just seems really hastily slapped together. Another strange thing missing from the game is a digitized version of the real Austin Powers pinball table. It's such a strange release but I love its weirdness.

>>9496679
Okay so the way the powerups work is that each colour is a different type of attack. To upgrade them you need to collect the same colour repeatedly without collecting the other colours, otherwise you go back to the lv1 version of the collected weapon. Try it, it will make a huge difference. Melee enemies that get close because itll either oneshot them or knock them back giving you room for a charge shot. They have very basic patterns to play around once you know how they work. Boss of stage 1 is a bit of a pain if you dont know the patterns and some require you get into position before the attack comes out. If the turret is spinning one way try to be one the end of that rotation so you have enough time to read the pattern before youre expected to dodge. Shifting levels and ducking is effective. You can do it!

>>9498287
Change your mindset on single player games and youll appreciate them more. Pattern recognition is a form of puzzle solving, where the player is rewarded for how quickly they can recognize and adapt to a challenge with an equal amount of skill execution thrown on top. The appeal of a single player action game is that once you've passed a skill check you move onto the next one in increasing levels of difficulty and complexity. Pvp and multiplayer in general is great for creating dynamic and evolving scenarios but it also doesnt give the player and clear linear progression of their skills or promise any variety to foster it. Theres a reason at uni I mostly made couch multiplayer games. It was a cheap shorthand to getting emergent play out of a few design elements. Put a character controller in a room with a ball they have to roll into a basket? Boring. Put two character controllers in a room with baskets for each of them? Watch the strategies emerge, add a few rock paper scissors elements and boom. good grades. As a player you feel more intelligent but as a designer you come to appreciate how brilliant a well designed single player game is. Anyway go play Sin And Punishment (the wii version) right now and give yourself 40 lashes when youre done. Also drop the high iq stuff its obnoxious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9497897
Considering I personally have experienced this trying to get into shmups myself yeah i'd say its a barrier for newcomers at the least. It was latter half of thunderforce iv. I prefer games give me a decent level of power by default but give me more power through skilled play which requires that i maintain that skill to keep the power from decaying in some way. I see a lot of shmups where the skill needed actually declines to more powerful you become. The scrolling sections become pushovers and the only threats being anything that can live to get a shot off and the bosses that can tank the damage. Its easy to develop bad habits when you spend most of a stage not seeing a single attack pattern. When a threat comes around that does challenge your damage output losing that output is a death sentence when you have so little familiarity with the stage. I think its more a case of power being to static 100-0 than a smooth gradient that causes the issue. As someone not too familiar with shmups i don't know how many buck that trend though or if Id see past it with more practice.

>>9494086
I mean, it did release in some form, but man, imagine how different the Sonic landscape might've been if Sonic Team had their priorities straight and swapped Sonic Adventure and NiGHTS into Dreams.
Saturn Adventure gets:
>a more focused, streamlined experience (ie. no techdemo crap like fishing)
>the swansong of the original character design aesthetic (or alternatively, the redesigns never happen because Sega wouldn't feel the need to reinvvent his image after skipping mainline 3D)
NiGHTS into Dreamcast gets:
>more exposure as a unique launch title and appropriately becomes the unofficial Dreamcast mascot
>Self content intact to extend the game's life
It's win-win.
BONUS: Sonic X-Treme potentially:
>gets further along in development due to the team not wasting weeks of work on the NiGHTS engine
>possibly far enough that Sega's PC division is interested in finishing it instead of turning it down as they did in this time-line

Sadly, it supposedly got canned in favor of the Mario Clash minigame that became its own game (we have seen a pic of the Mario Bros.-style minigame, picrel, and it looked more like traditional Mario Bros. than 3-D Mario Bros., unless that minigame had multiple configurations).

>>9502203
MaskROM prices plummeted right in the middle of the 64DD's development. Nintendo wasn't expecting to be able to stick 32-64MB rom chips inside the cartridges at a reasonable cost so once that became viable the 64DD became redundant. Nintendo knew it, too. That's why they sold it through mail order and shit. Had they not been sitting on an already finished product they probably would have just canceled it outright.

>>9500337
It's really hard to say. The story of the Dreamcast is more than just the success or failure of the hardware in relation to competing models. Somehow, there existed a brief period where multiple different teams of creative, passionate individuals came together on this platform to produce a little slice in history of vivid, unique, entertaining, sometimes downright experimental games. It was a rare brief peak of free creative spirit and it's hard to really pin down what cultivates these, other than living in a vibrant, enjoyable time where individualism that nourishes such minds and talents flourishes. The Dreamcast's golden age lasted from roughly 1999 to 2001. What happened in late 2001? I don't want to pin it down to just one certain event, but there's too many variables to consider whether such a soulful time in gaming could last much longer than these fleeting, shining moments.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Nintendo 64 games run at high resolution
Majority of N64 games run at standard 320x240 resolution. Some games support higher resolution with the expansion pack but less than a dozen reach 640x480. For the rest it's some weird resolution like 400×440 or 480x360.
https://nintendo.fandom.com/wiki/Nintendo_64_Expansion_Pak
>Nintendo 64 games have higher polygon count than PS1 games
N64 supports 160000 polygons per second with standard microcode. If you switch off some hardware features like Z-buffering, N64 theoretically can reach 500000-600000 polygons per second but these would be very basic unfiltered and untextured polygons.
PS1 has 180000 for textured polygons and 360000 polygons per second for untextured polygons. Most games use a combination of two.
In practice, no N64 game has a polycount outside of PS1 capabilities.
>Nintendo 64 games have bad textures because of cart size limitations
Only partially true. The most significant bottleneck is 4kb texture cache which takes CPU cycles to be updated. In short, the bigger textures you use, the worse framerate you have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9502590
Untrue. Japanese 8 came out on PlayStation first in late 1996, English 8 came out on PlayStation around the same time as Japanese 8 on Saturn in early 1997, then finally English 8 came out on Saturn. The confusion comes from a poorly worded segment on G4 that didn't specify it was it was talking about Sony America. Note that the extra anthology booklet only came out in North America. On top of that, the segment never even claimed that the Saturn version was the original vision like it was cited. It was all-around misunderstood.
The leaked early protos are of the PlayStation version for MM8 & Saturn version version for MMX4, supporting this further.

Castlevania 1's a much tighter game with a better hard mode (not being able to start a run on it sucks, though), 3's got shitloads more replay value even discounting how the JP version is fairly different, Bloodlines is a much more engaging and fast paced game and Rondo has better presentation and boss fights. 4 isn't bad, it's just the least impressive of its contemporaries. >>9498157
Konami had a policy of

A. Making games with the same name for brand confusion purchases.
B. Making alternate games for different consoles to build their fan base through product variety (if one isn't popular, the other likely will be).
C. Flooding the market with cheap games to crowd out competition.
D. Making what were essentially altered remakes to keep dev costs down.

They were fucking cut-throat. Nintendo had to enforce a game-per-publisher limit on Famicom to stop companies like Konami from hurting both the Nintendo brand and hurting partner sales, and Konami just made a shell company to get around it.

This is why you have Akumajou Dracula (FC, MSX, Arcade, SFC).

>>9498054
Two problems with the control specifically.
1. The ability to flail your whip is completely superfluous outside of the Dracula fight and the fact that it activates whenever you hit a directional button while attacking means that buffering movement while trying to attack will randomly make your whip go flaccid when you're trying to get a crucial second hit on something. This is also a problem when you're jumping and trying to attack and air-control at the same time, your attack will cancel mid-windup because the game thinks you're trying to flail in mid-air for some reason.
2. Eight-directional whipping renders several combat sections completely trivial to the point that it seems as if it was designed without it in mind.

Other problems:
>Swinging from grapple points is a dumb, irritating movement gimmick that always feels dangerous and slippery
>The 8-2 platforms can give you unwinnable patterns and the B-2 stairs are too punishing
>Because the combat is so trivial, frustrating platforming becomes the only legitimate challenge and is not fun
>Most boss fights are brute-force slugfests
>A few of the music tracks are completely absurd (3-3)
>Hard mode is nothing but more ambush bats

All that being said, it's still a really good, really fun game. It just has problems that people notice when they play it.

Within the context of the Castlevania series it's the odd game out, and this causes hardcore fans of the series to dismiss the game for being easier and not as tight and deliberate as Rondo of Blood. It also doesn't push the series forward the way 3 did, only having one route and one playable character.
Personally I don't care about any of that. The game's fun as hell, looks great, and has kickass music. I really like the atmosphere is basically Halloween: The Holiday: The Game.

>>9499630
Recently played through LoI for the first time

+
Great music.
Great atmosphere and art direction. Did a great job of bringing the SOTN vibe to the 3D.

+/-
Cheesy story/VA. I actually found it entertaining and charming, but objectively speaking this is probably a flaw.

-
Boring combat. You can pretty much just mash square and triangle mindlessly to kill 90% of the enemies.
Mediocre level design. Most of the game is just empty hallways or a big room where the doors shut and you're forced to fight the aforementioned mindless goons.
Godawful platforming. Despite there only being a handful of platforming sections, there were still too many. No idea how this got past the playtesting stage.

Overall the game kinda felt like the 1st DMC, but without the fun combat. Worth a playthrough for Igavania diehards, but not much else. I plan on playing CoD too eventually as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Solar Jetman's last level.
The game has a password system, but it doesn't save your entire inventory so it's pretty much worthless. If you want to make a serious stab at beating it without cheats, you gotta play through. Given how fucking long a single level can be, and how difficult it is to make progress, just getting to the final level is a real chore. Towards the end, it's a slog of pushing to the next bit of fuel and fighting your way back to the mothership without losing a jetpod or a life. The harder the enemies, the more you'll need to travel back to the mothership for a complete refill. The last planet before the final level is fucking massive on-top of that.
Then you reach the final level only to discover they change the physics and controls without telling you. All game long you've been playing a space-physics simulator with angle, thrust, and gravity. Up and down just raised or lowered your shields. Suddenly the last level controls like a standard shoot-em-up game, and physics no longer exist. Neither do your shields or durability. You could bounce off the walls in the rest of the game, here they are instant-death. Game doesn't tell you this either.
All those lives you have stockpiled mean nothing now. Die once on the final level and it's instant Game Over with no continue. Password to the previous planet will effectively leave you crippled and unable to finish the job. If you tap a wall and die, you'll need to play through the entire game again to stand a reasonable chance of beating the final planet and accessing the final level again.

>>9501758
Soul = had some degree of effort put into it (especially if the hardware was extremely limited), gives you a warm feeling inside, was made to fit someone's vision/fantasy rather than to sate the desires of the widest audience possible.

I think the last point might be a big factor in what makes people call out a lot of new stuff as "soulless". Most people weren't connected back then so a lot of art felt especially idiosyncratic. But now that most of us are connected to the internet and are bumping elbows with everyone and drinking from the same watering hole its hard for things to feel unique anymore without feeling either like we've seen it before or that it's meant to appeal to the masses (the backrooms)
